newsitem.title: CANADA: CWB sees likely lower China sales weigh on wheat.
newsitem.headline: CWB sees likely lower China sales weigh on wheat.

text.p: Expectations that China should have a bumper wheat harvest weighed on world price projections issued by the Canadian Wheat Board Thursday, a CWB market analyst said Friday.
"There's more supplies and possibly lower import demand, especially from China," CWB market analyst Larry Sawatzky said.
The United States Department of Agriculture on August 12 forecast 1996/97 Chinese wheat imports at 8.0 million tonnes, down a third from the previous year's demand of 12.0 million tonnes.
Since last month China cancelled more than 1.0 million tonnes of U.S. wheat purchases for 1996/97 citing concerns over TCK smut fungus.

"Those Chinese cancellations of U.S. wheat sales depressed the market. People were saying: 'Holy cow, they're backing out of all these sales, their crop must be fairly good.' That definitely had a negative impact," Sawatzky said.
The CWB lowered its estimate of world prices for its benchmark No.1 Canada Western Red Spring Wheat C$13 a tonne to the C$232-252 a tonne range from C$245-265 range in July.
